author: Tooba Shaikh
title: Mohammed Siraj Visits His Hometown On His B‚Äôday; Recalls The Time He Used To Flip Rumali Rotis And Burn His Hands
text:
The famous cricket player, Mohammed Siraj, recently celebrated his 30th birthday. A favourite among many, this talented bowler recently visited his hometown in Hyderabad, Telangana. The Board of Control for Cricket in India or the BCCI recently filmed a short video of him in his hometown. He regaled the viewers with anecdotes and memories of his childhood days and even got a bit emotional about all that he had to experience during his struggle days.
Mohammed Siraj Visits His Locality In Hyderabad
üè† ùôÉùô§ùô¢ùôöùôòùô§ùô¢ùôûùô£ùôú ùô®ùô•ùôöùôòùôûùôñùô° ùôõùô©. ùôàùô§ùôùùôñùô¢ùô¢ùôöùôô ùôéùôûùôßùôñùôü
As he celebrates his birthday, we head back to Hyderabad where it all began üëè
The pacer‚Äôs heartwarming success story is filled with struggles, nostalgia and good people ü§ó
You‚Äôve watched him bowl, now‚Ä¶
[pic.twitter.com/RfElTPrwmJ]
‚Äî BCCI (@BCCI)
[March 13, 2024]
Mohammed Siraj celebrated his birthday this year in his hometown. And the best part? He took his fans along with him. Siraj showed BCCI TV around his hood in Hyderabad. He even showed his neighbourhood in Hyderabad called Eidgah.
He showed people the ground where he grew up playing cricket and also his favourite chai spot in the city. At one point in the video, he gets a little sentimental while sharing that he used to work as a catered and helped his father, an autorickshaw driver who was the sole earning member of the family.
He said that he used to flip rumali rotis at the job till his hands burned. However, Siraj said he was grateful for the struggles and doesn‚Äôt regret it. He says that without those days of struggle, he perhaps wouldn‚Äôt have valued his success as much as he does now.
Also Read:
Mohammed Siraj Invited RCB Team To His Home To Relish Hyderabadi Biryani
Here‚Äôs What His Fans Had To Say About This Touching Video
This literally made me emotional
‚Äî PallabüáÆüá≥ (@Pallab200205)
[March 13, 2024]
The video won the hearts of many of his already-adoring fans. They took to the comment section to commend the struggle that he has had to go through to get to where he is today. Many people even wished him a happy birthday!
From being called as RUN MACHINE in IPL.
To‚Ä¶ Wicket taking machine for team üáÆüá≥
‚Äî Varun Giri (@Varungiri0)
[March 13, 2024]
Fans couldn‚Äôt stop gushing about how proud they were of their favourite bowler. Truly, his journey is quite inspiring.
Happy Birthday Miyan bhai
‚Äî Satya Prakash (@Satya_Prakash08)
[March 13, 2024]
Also Read:
Hyderabad Gets Its First-Ever Self-Cooking Station, Sparking A Culinary Revolution In The City
Are you an admirer of Mohammed Siraj? Let us know in the comments section below!
Cover Image Credits: @BCCI/X (Formerly, Twitter) and @mohammedsirajofficial/Instagram

author: @CambridgeIndy
title: New Year Honours 2024: Sharon Livermore made MBE for services to victims of domestic abuse after her own experience
text: New Year Honours 2024: Sharon Livermore made MBE for services to victims of domestic abuse after her own experience Sharon Livermore, from Cambridge, has been made MBE for services to the victims of domestic abuse. Sharon, a recruitment consultant, was stalked by her then husband during her 18-month marriage, culminating in his attempt to kidnap her outside her workplace in 2015. She has since [founded Domestic Abuse Education](https://www.cambridgeindependent.co.uk/news/i-married-a-monster-he-changed-on-our-9311634/) to train employers on how to support staff affected by abuse and encourage firms to create a ‚Äúsafe space‚Äù. Sharon, who is now director of Kameo Recruitment, said: ‚ÄúWhen I found out about the honour I just cried and cried. I felt completely overwhelmed. It has sunk in a bit, but it still doesn't feel real. ‚ÄúHopefully it will help me open more doors to be able to speak to new people, and just get people to be aware that there is an issue with domestic abuse and that employers can make a really positive impact for their employees. ‚ÄúThe main thing an employer can do is have a safe space. Unless the perpetrator works with the victim, which obviously does happen, you can create a safe space at work where victims can access support for specialist services, to be able to make choices to be able to leave the relationship potentially in a safe way. Or a place where they can just gain that knowledge that they don't have to know what the next steps look like for them. ‚ÄúI think employers don't realise that they can make a difference. They may think it's a home based issue, but it's not. It's everyone's business. I like to say any business can create a safe space, and make it easier for people to come forward and ask for support. And obviously, as part of that they can have education and training to be able to spot the signs in their colleagues and know how to signpost somebody and start what is often an awkward conversation.‚Äù Sharon has set up services to help domestic abuse victims after her own terrifying experiences. One day in 2015, Sharon confided in her boss that she was being stalked by her estranged husband and then reported it to the police. They arrested him and helped relocate her and her children to a place where they were safe. Weeks later, on November 4, Sharon was leaving the office and walking towards her car when she noticed the windows were unusually steamed up. As she got in, she spotted her picnic blanket, usually kept in the boot, was in the footwell. ‚ÄúI smelt aftershave. Something seriously wasn‚Äôt right here,‚Äù said Sharon She leapt out of her car and flipped the boot open to find her ex-husband, curled up inside, armed with knives and cable ties. He jumped out and chased Sharon, who was ‚Äúfrightened for her life‚Äù, as she ran back towards the office. He managed to grab her and she cowered down on the floor, trying to protect herself. But upon hearing her screams, a colleague rushed to her aid and managed to push him off. He ran to Sharon‚Äôs car and, as the engine was still running, he sped off, only to be arrested later by officers. He was found guilty of attempted kidnap, taking a vehicle without the owner‚Äôs consent and was sentenced to four years in prison. Sharon said: ‚ÄúWhat I went through has defined me, but in a good way. After living through an experience that is so fearful and traumatic, I'm not scared of things like other people potentially would be now. I was able to set up my own recruitment business and build a platform to deliver domestic abuse education. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really excited about going to Buckingham Palace. I never thought that was something I would experience and just to be there and be around other people that have made a difference and have been honoured will be incredible.‚Äù Sharon won [Business Person of the Year](https://www.cambridgeindependent.co.uk/business/winners-of-the-cambridge-independent-sme-cambridgeshire-busi-9332691/) at the 2023 Cambridge Independent Cambridgeshire Business Awards.

author: Saleen Martin
title: 'May this keep you safe from harm': WWII era Bible returned to New York veteran's family
text: Lost Bible returned to slain USAAF airman from World War II [Saleen Martin](https://www.usatoday.com/staff/7245115001/saleen-martin/) During World War II, a woman bought three brothers Bibles to protect their hearts and guide them as they set out for battle. The Bible had a metal cover on the front with the inscription ‚ÄúMay this keep you safe from harm." Two of the brothers made it home, while the other, Lt. Edsel J. McKnight of the United States Army Air Forces, was shot down off the coast of France. His Bible was mailed to the family but was lost sometime after. This month, his family finally got it back. Ava Coogan's family is from Albany, New York and they found the Bible in late December while going through their late matriarch‚Äôs belongings. On Jan. 11, Coogan met Lt. McKnight‚Äôs sister-in-law and returned the Bible to her, allowing her to put it back in its rightful place, next to the ones his brothers brought back home from war. ‚ÄòI kept playing with it and flipping through the pages‚Äô Coogan‚Äôs uncle and mother found the Bible in a stack of books. Their mother, Rosanne Vartanian, died nearly 20 years ago but was a collector and loved garage sales. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just so random that my grandmother had the urge to pick that up,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúShe bought random things. There was no rhyme or reason to it. It was with a stack of other books.‚Äù Coogan decided to research the Bible and found out soldiers often took them to war. Some can be found in museums. ‚ÄúThe whole premise of it was that the metal cover on the front is like a hard shield,‚Äù Coogan told USA TODAY. ‚ÄúThey would put it in their coat pockets ‚Ä¶ like the front breast pocket ‚Ä¶ that cover would protect their heart from bullets.‚Äù Lt. McKnight‚Äôs name was also written in the Bible, said Coogan, who was drawn to the Bible for some reason. She couldn‚Äôt put it down, she recalled. ‚ÄúI kept playing with it and flipping through the pages,‚Äù she said. She noticed that the Bible‚Äôs front cover had a slice in it, almost like something was underneath it. She examined it more closely and found a piece of paper folded up inside. She asked her uncle for help, who carefully used a butter knife to get the slip of paper out. Once they retrieved the piece of paper from under the Bible‚Äôs cover, they saw that it was a plea for the Bible‚Äôs safe return to an address not too far away. Although there was no area code, there was a phone number listed, so the family added their own area code and called. ‚ÄúI was just hoping for the best,‚Äù Coogan said. ‚ÄúWe found out that number worked.‚Äù Lieutenant was shot down off the coast of France When Coogan called the number written in the note, she spoke to a woman named Fay, Lt. McKnight‚Äôs sister-in-law. They organized a meetup on Jan. 11 to return the Bible to the family, who is from Porter Corners, part of Saratoga County in eastern New York. Lt. McKnight served in the U.S. Air Force‚Äôs 365th Fighter Group and 388th Fighter Squadron. He was flying in a Thunderbolt fighter aircraft in 1944 when he was shot down off the coast of France, [online records](https://rafbeaulieu.co.uk/honouring-the-airmen-of-raf-beaulieu/) show. Fay told Coogan and her family that Lt. McKnight has two brothers. All three of the brothers served in WWII. Fay‚Äôs husband, Ray, said his Bible saved his life. ‚ÄúHe got shot during the war and it hit where the Bible was, covering his heart, and the bullet went into his arm instead,‚Äù Coogan said. Once Lt. McKnight was killed, his belongings were shipped back home to the family. His sister-in-law had all three Bibles on a bookshelf on display. One day, the family was preparing to go to church. Her nephew borrowed the Bible, but knew it was so precious, the family decided to write a note with contact information in case it were ever lost. ‚ÄúHe didn't lose it,‚Äù Coogan said. ‚ÄúHe brought it back after church and I guess what happened is after someone passed in their family, they had an estate sale ‚Ä¶ and it just accidentally went out with a stack of books.‚Äù It ended up in Coogan‚Äôs grandmother‚Äôs hands, she said. Returning the Bible to the McKnight family was quite the enlightening experience, Coogan said. ‚ÄúThat was really cool because that's when we kind of got to hear their story,‚Äù she said.

author: John Pike
title: Newspapers Laud Respected Comrade Kim Jong Un's Army-Building Exploits
text:
Newspapers Laud Respected Comrade Kim Jong Un's Army-Building Exploits
Korean Central News Agency of DPRK
Pyongyang, December 30 (KCNA) -- Leading newspapers of the DPRK Saturday dedicate articles to the 12th anniversary of the respected General Secretary Kim Jong Un 's assumption of the supreme commandership of the armed forces of the DPRK.
Thanks to the day, the true feature and nature of the revolutionary armed forces of the DPRK have been firmly preserved, a decisive guarantee for the steady continuity of the history and traditions of invincibility provided and the country's honor, dignity and might as the strongest military power demonstrated to the world, Rodong Sinmun notes, and goes on:
This year witnessed the attainment of the major goals of the five-year plan for development of national defence capabilities, continuous development of new strategic weapons, rapid progress in the overall national defences and possession of even a reconnaissance satellite. The dignity and absolute power of our state, which no other forces can overpower, has been fully demonstrated to the world.
Such eye-opening successes, achieved in the bolstering of the national defence capabilities thanks to the energetic guidance and patriotic devotion of the respected General Secretary, are proud ones that highlighted the mightiness and invincible spirit of the DPRK.
Celebrating the above-said anniversary, the people of the DPRK keenly realize the truth that the country is strong and their dignity and happiness is ensured as they are led by the peerlessly brilliant commander.
An eternal guarantee for adding glory to the prestige and power of Juche Korea at the highest level is provided when we faithfully uphold the leadership of the respected General Secretary.
Stressing that the respected Comrade Kim Jong Un represents the mightiness and great dignity of the country, Minju Joson says the future of Juche Korea is immensely rosy as it is holding the peerlessly great commander in high esteem as the supreme commander of the armed forces. -0-
|

author: Studentaffairsmkt
title: NSU SAA Hosts Celebrate Sound (Feb 17) ‚Äì NSU SharkFINS
text: Join the NSU Student Academy of Audiology in their initiative to promote hearing awareness by participating in Celebrate Sound! When: Saturday, February 17, 2024 Location: Topeekeegee Yugnee Park 3300 North Park Road Hollywood, FL 33021 Time: 9:00 a.m. ‚Äì 1:00 p.m. This walkathon aims to raise funds for the Hearing Charities of America‚Äôs hearing aid project. The event includes complimentary hearing screenings and welcomes participants of all ages to a day filled with fun activities. Attendees can enjoy silent auctions, games, and indulge in snacks and beverages. Registration is $25 for adults and $15 for children. All proceeds will contribute to the Hearing Charities of America‚Äôs cause. Click here [for additional details and to register](https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fp2p.onecause.com%2Fcelebratesoundfortlauderdale&data=05%7C02%7Cposterprinting%40nova.edu%7C1cb53bc75e1e42209d9d08dc0d708472%7C2c2b2d312e3e4df1b571fb37c042ff1b%7C1%7C0%7C638400024122361290%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=1Zn%2BbUIsGgmvLK4WR4BnNbHToPmoBLxYvbvXrPiIHw4%3D&reserved=0) Let‚Äôs come together to Celebrate Sound and make a difference!
